hemorrhage; INR, international normalized ratio; MRA, magnetic resonance angiography; MRI,\nmagnetic resonance imaging; NHS/NICE, National Collaborating Centre for Chronic Conditions; NIHSS, National Institute of Health Stroke\nScale; NPO, nil per os (nothing by mouth); PTT, partial thromboplastin time; SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network; TIA, transient\nischemic attack.\n\nThe following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel.\n\nModule 1 Implementation Considerations\nGeneral considerations\n• Development and/or updating of ED acute stroke protocols to ensure communication with CritiCall Ontario as soon as\npossible to determine treatment and transport decisions for patients presenting with potentially disabling, acute\nneurological symptoms suggestive of an acute stroke within 6.0 hours of symptom onset and considered to be a\npotential candidate for intravenous thrombolysis and/or endovascular therapy (EVT)\n• Regional planning for access to acute stroke EVT should consider the following:\no The importance of rapid triage, assessment and brain imaging (including parallel vascular imaging) of acute\nstroke patients who are potential candidates for EVT.\no Development of regional and provincial bypass and repatriation agreements\no Sites should establish rapid communication protocols with closest EVT site(s), facilitated through CritiCall\nOntario.\no Development of regional protocols to support a “drip and ship” process.\n• Capacity Planning is needed to develop access to EVT for patients living within regions where currently there is a\ngreater than two (2) hour patient transfer time to an EVT Centre\n• Where feasible, development of processes and protocols to facilitate EMS to divert patients to regional or district\nstroke and /Endovascular Treatment centres if there is suspicion of stroke\n• The process for EMS prenotification of the receiving stroke hospital about a stroke patient arrival should be better\nestablished to ensure acute stroke teams receive timely and detailed information\n• Collaboration between local EMS and institutions that provide stroke services should occur in all stroke networks\nacross the province to support quality improvement initiatives that facilitate access to stroke care\n• Ongoing education should be provided to EMS crews about the recognition of stroke symptoms and regional medical\nredirect protocols, including time sensitive treatments such as thrombolysis,EVT, patient transport monitoring and\nmanagement.\n• Upon receiving EMS prenotification, the receiving hospital’s acute stroke team should be contacted and called to the\nED (for appropriate patients)\n• Standardized stroke assessment and treatment protocols/tools should be developed and used in all Ontario hospital\nEDs\n• Access should be increased in all hospitals to either stroke physician experts or radiologists who can interpret brain\nimaging urgently and allow for full assessment and treatment with tPA thrombolysis within target door to needle time\nof less than 60 minutes in 90% of treated patients and a median door to needle time of 30 mins. of patient arrival for\nappropriate patients\n• Sufficient human resources capacity should be ensured so that patients can be diagnosed and treated in a timely\nmanner\n• To facilitate early assessment, hospital-level CTAS I or CTAS II access to diagnostic imaging should be established\nfor suspected stroke patients\n• Rapid turnaround times for lab work should be negotiated in hospitals that provide tPA thrombolysis for ischemic\nstroke patients to facilitate rapid assessment and treatment\n• Efforts to raise public awareness about the symptoms of stroke and when to contact 911 should continue to be\nenhanced and funded\n• Capacity planning to ensure access to CT/CTA should include:\no Training for CT technologists\no Adoption of provincial CT/CTA Protocol\no Human resource availability\no Communication processes with EVT Centre experts\nAbbreviations: CTAS, Canadian Triage and Acuity Scale; ED, emergency department; EMS, emergency medical services; tPA, tissue\nplasminogen activator.', 'reviewed_process_text': "\n  \n  \n  \n    \n      \n      \n        \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n      \n    \n    \n      \n      \n        \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n      \n      \n    \n    \n      \n        \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n      \n    \n    \n      \n      \n      \n    \n    \n      \n      \n        \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n      \n      \n        \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n      \n    \n    \n      \n    \n    \n      \n        \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n      \n    \n    \n      \n        \n          \n          \n          \n            \n              \n            \n            \n              \n            \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n      \n    \n    \n      \n    \n  \n", 'extra_knowledge': '', 'format': "\nWhen the process starts, please output ''\nAn activity is represented as follows:\n\nThe exclusive gateway is represented as follows:\n\n  \n    \n  \n  \n    \n  \n\nThe parallel gateway is represented as follows:\n\n  \n    \n  \n  \n    \n  \n\nThe inclusive gateway is represented as follows:\n\n  \n    \n  \n  \n    \n  \n\nAt the end of the process, please output ''\n\nThere are a few requirements that should be noted when generating process text:\n    1) role, action, objects and id in an activity represent the subject of the activity, the activity behavior, the items needed to perform in the activity and the activity id, respectively.\n    2) There are at least two branches within the exclusive gateway and the parallel gateway.\n    3) Activity, gateway, and branch id attributes must be unique.\n    4) When the branch in the exclusive gateway has a condition, fill the condition into the condition attribute. When the branch unconditional within the exclusive gateway, the condition attribute of the branch =''. However, all branches within a exclusive gateway can only be conditional, or both unconditional.\n    5) The branch in the parallel gateway has no condition attribute.\n    6) Each branch in the inclusive gateway must have condition.\n    7) There must be at least one activity inside the branch tag.\n    8) The activity of a sequential relation need not be represented by a gateway, that is, there is no 'sequenceGateway' label.\n", 'examples': ' ', 'suggestions': 'Suggested modification: Move the activity "Provide cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies to all patients (admitted or discharged)" (id=\'activity18\') to the end of the process, immediately before the process end tag, so that it occurs after all other diagnostic and management activities are completed.\n\nReason: According to extra knowledge point 1, the cross-continuum secondary prevention activity should be the last activity before process completion, ensuring that all acute assessment and management steps are finished prior to secondary prevention planning. This sequencing better reflects clinical workflow and guideline intent.'} |

[2025-30-06 14:03:02 INFO] flask app.py did not start for online log
[2025-30-06 14:03:02 INFO] Knowledge Graph Advisor: **[Start Chat]**

[You're a process design expert. Now, we share a common interest in collaborating to successfully complete a task assigned by a new customer.
You are familiar with exclusive gateway, parallel gateway and inclusive gateway in BPMN. Your main responsibilities include process generation, process refinement, process review and so on, guided by team leader.
You model the process of a clinical practice guideline to a clinical pathway.
Here is a new customer's task: Module 1: Early Assessment
This module identifies best practices for the early assessment of suspected stroke. Patients typically
present at the ED, but the same practices should be followed at an outpatient clinic or when patients
are directly admitted to acute care. The recommendations emphasize assessing the patient to inform
clinical decision-making and determine the most appropriate pathway.
Module 1 Recommended Practices 
1.1 Initial evaluation
1.1.1 Rapid initial evaluation should be conducted for airway,
breathing, and circulation
1.2 Initial examinations
1.2.1 All patients should undergo a neurological examination to
determine focal neurological deficits and assess stroke severity on a
standardized stroke scale (NIHSS or CNS for stroke)
1.2.2 Patients presenting with potentially disabling, acute neurological
symptoms suggestive of an acute stroke within 6.0 hours of symptom
onset, and may be considered for those in whom treatment can be
initiated within a 12- hour window from stroke symptom onset, who
meet clinical and imaging criteria may be considered for endovascular
therapy
1.2.3 All patients with suspected acute stroke (presenting within acute
stroke treatment time window) should undergo rapid brain imaging
(non-contrast CT or MRI) and CTA (Door to CT/CTA should be less
than twenty five minutes)
1.2.4. For patients with acute ischemic stroke that are clinically eligible
for acute stroke treatments, advanced CT imaging including CT and
multiphase CTA or Perfusion CT should be considered.
1.2.5 Brain imaging should be interpreted immediately by a health care
provider with expertise in reading/interpreting CT/CTA and/or MRI of
the brain
1.2.6 All patients should undergo ECG to detect atrial fibrillation and
other acute arrhythmias but should not delay acute treatment
1.2.7 A chest x-ray should not delay assessment for thrombolysis 
1.2.8 All patients should have the following blood work:
• CBC
• electrolytes
• creatinine
• glucose
• INR
• partial thromboplastin time
• troponin test (if clinically indicated)
1.3 Assessment and early management of dysphagia
1.3.1 All patients with stroke should be made NPO initially and have
their swallowing ability screened using a simple, valid, reliable, bedside
testing protocol as part of their initial assessment and before initiating
oral medication, fluid, or food
1.3.2 All patients with stroke who are not alert within the first 24 hours
should be monitored closely, and swallowing ability should be
screened when clinically appropriate
1.3.3 Patients with stroke presenting with features indicating dysphagia
or pulmonary aspiration should receive a full clinical assessment of
their swallowing ability by a speech-language pathologist or
appropriately trained specialist who would advise on swallowing ability
and the required consistency of diet and fluids
1.4 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies
1.4.1 All patients, whether admitted to hospital or discharged from the
ED, should be given appropriate cross-continuum secondary
prevention assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10)
1.5 Recommendation is not applicable to ischemic or ICH stroke patients
1.6 Initial examinations for ischemic stroke
1.6.1 Recommendation is not applicable to ischemic stroke patients
1.6.2 All other patients (presenting beyond 48 hours) with a TIA or
ischemic stroke should undergo vascular imaging of the brain and
neck arteries as soon as possible
1.7 Initial examinations for ICH
1.7.1 Patients with ICH must be treated as a medical emergency. ICH
should be promptly recognized, and patients should be evaluated
immediately by physicians with expertise in stroke management
1.7.2 Evaluation of patients with acute ICH should include questions
about anticoagulant therapy, measurement of platelet count, PTT, and
INR
1.7.3 Select patients with ICH should have CTA or MRA as soon as
possible
Abbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; Australia, Australian Clinical Guidelines for Stroke
Management; CBC, complete blood count; CSBPR, Canadian Stroke Best Practices Recommendations; CNS, Canadian Neurological Scale;
CT, computerized tomography; CTA, computed tomography angiography; ECG, electrocardiogram; ED, emergency department;EVT,
Endovascular Treatment ICH, intracerebral hemorrhage; INR, international normalized ratio; MRA, magnetic resonance angiography; MRI,
magnetic resonance imaging; NHS/NICE, National Collaborating Centre for Chronic Conditions; NIHSS, National Institute of Health Stroke
Scale; NPO, nil per os (nothing by mouth); PTT, partial thromboplastin time; SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network; TIA, transient
ischemic attack.

The following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel.

Module 1 Implementation Considerations
General considerations
• Development and/or updating of ED acute stroke protocols to ensure communication with CritiCall Ontario as soon as
possible to determine treatment and transport decisions for patients presenting with potentially disabling, acute
neurological symptoms suggestive of an acute stroke within 6.0 hours of symptom onset and considered to be a
potential candidate for intravenous thrombolysis and/or endovascular therapy (EVT)
• Regional planning for access to acute stroke EVT should consider the following:
o The importance of rapid triage, assessment and brain imaging (including parallel vascular imaging) of acute
stroke patients who are potential candidates for EVT.
o Development of regional and provincial bypass and repatriation agreements
o Sites should establish rapid communication protocols with closest EVT site(s), facilitated through CritiCall
Ontario.
o Development of regional protocols to support a “drip and ship” process.
• Capacity Planning is needed to develop access to EVT for patients living within regions where currently there is a
greater than two (2) hour patient transfer time to an EVT Centre
• Where feasible, development of processes and protocols to facilitate EMS to divert patients to regional or district
stroke and /Endovascular Treatment centres if there is suspicion of stroke
• The process for EMS prenotification of the receiving stroke hospital about a stroke patient arrival should be better
established to ensure acute stroke teams receive timely and detailed information
• Collaboration between local EMS and institutions that provide stroke services should occur in all stroke networks
across the province to support quality improvement initiatives that facilitate access to stroke care
• Ongoing education should be provided to EMS crews about the recognition of stroke symptoms and regional medical
redirect protocols, including time sensitive treatments such as thrombolysis,EVT, patient transport monitoring and
management.
• Upon receiving EMS prenotification, the receiving hospital’s acute stroke team should be contacted and called to the
ED (for appropriate patients)
• Standardized stroke assessment and treatment protocols/tools should be developed and used in all Ontario hospital
EDs
• Access should be increased in all hospitals to either stroke physician experts or radiologists who can interpret brain
imaging urgently and allow for full assessment and treatment with tPA thrombolysis within target door to needle time
of less than 60 minutes in 90% of treated patients and a median door to needle time of 30 mins. of patient arrival for
appropriate patients
• Sufficient human resources capacity should be ensured so that patients can be diagnosed and treated in a timely
manner
• To facilitate early assessment, hospital-level CTAS I or CTAS II access to diagnostic imaging should be established
for suspected stroke patients
• Rapid turnaround times for lab work should be negotiated in hospitals that provide tPA thrombolysis for ischemic
stroke patients to facilitate rapid assessment and treatment
• Efforts to raise public awareness about the symptoms of stroke and when to contact 911 should continue to be
enhanced and funded
• Capacity planning to ensure access to CT/CTA should include:
o Training for CT technologists
o Adoption of provincial CT/CTA Protocol
o Human resource availability
o Communication processes with EVT Centre experts
Abbreviations: CTAS, Canadian Triage and Acuity Scale; ED, emergency department; EMS, emergency medical services; tPA, tissue
plasminogen activator..
To complete the task, I will give you one or more instructions, and you must help me to write a specific solution that appropriately solves the requested instruction based on your expertise and my needs.]

Task: Module 1: Early Assessment
This module identifies best practices for the early assessment of suspected stroke. Patients typically
present at the ED, but the same practices should be followed at an outpatient clinic or when patients
are directly admitted to acute care. The recommendations emphasize assessing the patient to inform
clinical decision-making and determine the most appropriate pathway.
Module 1 Recommended Practices 
1.1 Initial evaluation
1.1.1 Rapid initial evaluation should be conducted for airway,
breathing, and circulation
1.2 Initial examinations
1.2.1 All patients should undergo a neurological examination to
determine focal neurological deficits and assess stroke severity on a
standardized stroke scale (NIHSS or CNS for stroke)
1.2.2 Patients presenting with potentially disabling, acute neurological
symptoms suggestive of an acute stroke within 6.0 hours of symptom
onset, and may be considered for those in whom treatment can be
initiated within a 12- hour window from stroke symptom onset, who
meet clinical and imaging criteria may be considered for endovascular
therapy
1.2.3 All patients with suspected acute stroke (presenting within acute
stroke treatment time window) should undergo rapid brain imaging
(non-contrast CT or MRI) and CTA (Door to CT/CTA should be less
than twenty five minutes)
1.2.4. For patients with acute ischemic stroke that are clinically eligible
for acute stroke treatments, advanced CT imaging including CT and
multiphase CTA or Perfusion CT should be considered.
1.2.5 Brain imaging should be interpreted immediately by a health care
provider with expertise in reading/interpreting CT/CTA and/or MRI of
the brain
1.2.6 All patients should undergo ECG to detect atrial fibrillation and
other acute arrhythmias but should not delay acute treatment
1.2.7 A chest x-ray should not delay assessment for thrombolysis 
1.2.8 All patients should have the following blood work:
• CBC
• electrolytes
• creatinine
• glucose
• INR
• partial thromboplastin time
• troponin test (if clinically indicated)
1.3 Assessment and early management of dysphagia
1.3.1 All patients with stroke should be made NPO initially and have
their swallowing ability screened using a simple, valid, reliable, bedside
testing protocol as part of their initial assessment and before initiating
oral medication, fluid, or food
1.3.2 All patients with stroke who are not alert within the first 24 hours
should be monitored closely, and swallowing ability should be
screened when clinically appropriate
1.3.3 Patients with stroke presenting with features indicating dysphagia
or pulmonary aspiration should receive a full clinical assessment of
their swallowing ability by a speech-language pathologist or
appropriately trained specialist who would advise on swallowing ability
and the required consistency of diet and fluids
1.4 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies
1.4.1 All patients, whether admitted to hospital or discharged from the
ED, should be given appropriate cross-continuum secondary
prevention assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10)
1.5 Recommendation is not applicable to ischemic or ICH stroke patients
1.6 Initial examinations for ischemic stroke
1.6.1 Recommendation is not applicable to ischemic stroke patients
1.6.2 All other patients (presenting beyond 48 hours) with a TIA or
ischemic stroke should undergo vascular imaging of the brain and
neck arteries as soon as possible
1.7 Initial examinations for ICH
1.7.1 Patients with ICH must be treated as a medical emergency. ICH
should be promptly recognized, and patients should be evaluated
immediately by physicians with expertise in stroke management
1.7.2 Evaluation of patients with acute ICH should include questions
about anticoagulant therapy, measurement of platelet count, PTT, and
INR
1.7.3 Select patients with ICH should have CTA or MRA as soon as
possible
Abbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; Australia, Australian Clinical Guidelines for Stroke
Management; CBC, complete blood count; CSBPR, Canadian Stroke Best Practices Recommendations; CNS, Canadian Neurological Scale;
CT, computerized tomography; CTA, computed tomography angiography; ECG, electrocardiogram; ED, emergency department;EVT,
Endovascular Treatment ICH, intracerebral hemorrhage; INR, international normalized ratio; MRA, magnetic resonance angiography; MRI,
magnetic resonance imaging; NHS/NICE, National Collaborating Centre for Chronic Conditions; NIHSS, National Institute of Health Stroke
Scale; NPO, nil per os (nothing by mouth); PTT, partial thromboplastin time; SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network; TIA, transient
ischemic attack.

The following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel.

Module 1 Implementation Considerations
General considerations
• Development and/or updating of ED acute stroke protocols to ensure communication with CritiCall Ontario as soon as
possible to determine treatment and transport decisions for patients presenting with potentially disabling, acute
neurological symptoms suggestive of an acute stroke within 6.0 hours of symptom onset and considered to be a
potential candidate for intravenous thrombolysis and/or endovascular therapy (EVT)
• Regional planning for access to acute stroke EVT should consider the following:
o The importance of rapid triage, assessment and brain imaging (including parallel vascular imaging) of acute
stroke patients who are potential candidates for EVT.
o Development of regional and provincial bypass and repatriation agreements
o Sites should establish rapid communication protocols with closest EVT site(s), facilitated through CritiCall
Ontario.
o Development of regional protocols to support a “drip and ship” process.
• Capacity Planning is needed to develop access to EVT for patients living within regions where currently there is a
greater than two (2) hour patient transfer time to an EVT Centre
• Where feasible, development of processes and protocols to facilitate EMS to divert patients to regional or district
stroke and /Endovascular Treatment centres if there is suspicion of stroke
• The process for EMS prenotification of the receiving stroke hospital about a stroke patient arrival should be better
established to ensure acute stroke teams receive timely and detailed information
• Collaboration between local EMS and institutions that provide stroke services should occur in all stroke networks
across the province to support quality improvement initiatives that facilitate access to stroke care
• Ongoing education should be provided to EMS crews about the recognition of stroke symptoms and regional medical
redirect protocols, including time sensitive treatments such as thrombolysis,EVT, patient transport monitoring and
management.
• Upon receiving EMS prenotification, the receiving hospital’s acute stroke team should be contacted and called to the
ED (for appropriate patients)
• Standardized stroke assessment and treatment protocols/tools should be developed and used in all Ontario hospital
EDs
• Access should be increased in all hospitals to either stroke physician experts or radiologists who can interpret brain
imaging urgently and allow for full assessment and treatment with tPA thrombolysis within target door to needle time
of less than 60 minutes in 90% of treated patients and a median door to needle time of 30 mins. of patient arrival for
appropriate patients
• Sufficient human resources capacity should be ensured so that patients can be diagnosed and treated in a timely
manner
• To facilitate early assessment, hospital-level CTAS I or CTAS II access to diagnostic imaging should be established
for suspected stroke patients
• Rapid turnaround times for lab work should be negotiated in hospitals that provide tPA thrombolysis for ischemic
stroke patients to facilitate rapid assessment and treatment
• Efforts to raise public awareness about the symptoms of stroke and when to contact 911 should continue to be
enhanced and funded
• Capacity planning to ensure access to CT/CTA should include:
o Training for CT technologists
o Adoption of provincial CT/CTA Protocol
o Human resource availability
o Communication processes with EVT Centre experts
Abbreviations: CTAS, Canadian Triage and Acuity Scale; ED, emergency department; EMS, emergency medical services; tPA, tissue
plasminogen activator.
Current process text:
<process>
  <activity role='triage nurse' action='Conduct rapid initial evaluation for airway, breathing, and circulation' objects='patient' id='activity1-abc'/>
  <activity role='clinician' action='Perform neurological examination including assessment of stroke severity using standardized stroke scale (NIHSS or CNS)' objects='patient' id='activity2-1-2'/>
  <parallelGateway id='parallelgateway1'>
    <branch id='branch1'>
      <activity role='clinician' action='Determine if patient presents with potentially disabling, acute neurological symptoms suggestive of acute stroke within 6 hours of symptom onset and if treatment can be initiated within 12 hours' objects='patient history, symptom onset time' id='activity3'/>
      <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway1'>
        <branch condition='Meets criteria for endovascular therapy consideration' id='branch2'>
          <activity role='clinician' action='Consider patient for endovascular therapy (EVT) if clinical and imaging criteria are met' objects='clinical criteria, imaging criteria' id='activity4'/>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='Does not meet criteria for endovascular therapy consideration' id='branch3'>
          <activity role='clinician' action='Proceed with standard acute stroke assessment and management' objects='patient' id='activity5'/>
        </branch>
      </exclusiveGateway>
    </branch>
    <branch id='branch4'>
      <activity role='radiology technologist' action='Perform rapid brain imaging (non-contrast CT or MRI) and CTA within 25 minutes of arrival' objects='patient, CT/MRI scanner, CTA' id='activity6'/>
      <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway2'>
        <branch condition='Patient is clinically eligible for acute ischemic stroke treatments' id='branch5'>
          <activity role='radiology technologist' action='Perform advanced CT imaging including CT, multiphase CTA or Perfusion CT' objects='patient, advanced CT imaging' id='activity7'/>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='Patient is not clinically eligible for acute ischemic stroke treatments' id='branch6'>
          <activity role='radiology technologist' action='Skip advanced CT imaging' objects='' id='activity8'/>
        </branch>
      </exclusiveGateway>
      <activity role='stroke physician or radiologist' action='Interpret brain imaging immediately' objects='CT/CTA/MRI images' id='activity9'/>
    </branch>
    <branch id='branch8'>
      <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway-chestxray'>
        <branch condition='Chest x-ray clinically indicated' id='branch8-1'>
          <activity role='clinician' action='Order chest x-ray (should not delay assessment for thrombolysis)' objects='patient, chest x-ray' id='activity11'/>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='Chest x-ray not clinically indicated' id='branch8-2'>
          <activity role='clinician' action='Do not order chest x-ray' objects='patient' id='activity11-2'/>
        </branch>
      </exclusiveGateway>
    </branch>
    <branch id='branch9'>
      <activity role='clinician' action='Order blood work' objects='patient' id='activity12-1'/>
      <activity role='nurse or phlebotomist' action='Collect blood samples' objects='patient, blood collection materials' id='activity12-2'/>
      <activity role='nurse or phlebotomist' action='Send blood samples to laboratory' objects='blood samples, laboratory' id='activity12-3'/>
    </branch>
    <branch id='branch10'>
      <activity role='nurse' action='Make all patients with stroke NPO initially and screen swallowing ability using simple, valid, reliable bedside protocol before oral medication, fluid, or food' objects='patient, swallowing screening tool' id='activity13'/>
      <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway3'>
        <branch condition='Patient not alert within first 24 hours' id='branch11'>
          <activity role='nurse' action='Monitor closely and screen swallowing ability when clinically appropriate' objects='patient' id='activity14'/>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='Patient alert within first 24 hours' id='branch12'>
          <activity role='nurse' action='Continue standard monitoring' objects='patient' id='activity15'/>
        </branch>
      </exclusiveGateway>
      <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway4'>
        <branch condition='Patient presents with features indicating dysphagia or pulmonary aspiration' id='branch13'>
          <activity role='speech-language pathologist or trained specialist' action='Perform full clinical assessment of swallowing ability and advise on swallowing and required consistency of diet and fluids' objects='patient' id='activity16'/>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='No features of dysphagia or pulmonary aspiration' id='branch14'>
          <activity role='nurse' action='Continue routine care' objects='patient' id='activity17'/>
        </branch>
      </exclusiveGateway>
    </branch>
    <branch id='branch11'>
      <activity role='clinician' action='Provide cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies to all patients (admitted or discharged)' objects='patient, prevention protocols' id='activity18'/>
    </branch>
    <branch id='branch12'>
      <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway5'>
        <branch condition='Patient presenting beyond 48 hours with TIA or ischemic stroke' id='branch15'>
          <activity role='clinician' action='Order vascular imaging of brain and neck arteries as soon as possible' objects='patient, vascular imaging' id='activity19'/>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='Patient presenting within 48 hours or not TIA/ischemic stroke' id='branch16'>
          <activity role='clinician' action='Proceed with standard care' objects='patient' id='activity20'/>
        </branch>
      </exclusiveGateway>
    </branch>
    <branch id='branch13'>
      <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway6'>
        <branch condition='Patient has ICH' id='branch17'>
          <activity role='stroke physician' action='Recognize ICH as medical emergency and evaluate immediately' objects='patient' id='activity21'/>
          <activity role='stroke physician' action='Assess anticoagulant therapy, measure platelet count, PTT, and INR' objects='patient, lab results' id='activity22'/>
          <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway7'>
            <branch condition='Select ICH patients as indicated' id='branch18'>
              <activity role='radiology technologist' action='Perform CTA or MRA as soon as possible' objects='patient, CTA/MRA' id='activity23'/>
            </branch>
            <branch condition='Not indicated for CTA/MRA' id='branch19'>
              <activity role='stroke physician' action='Continue with standard ICH management' objects='patient' id='activity24'/>
            </branch>
          </exclusiveGateway>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='Patient does not have ICH' id='branch20'>
          <activity role='clinician' action='Continue with appropriate stroke pathway' objects='patient' id='activity25'/>
        </branch>
      </exclusiveGateway>
    </branch>
    <branch id='branch14'>
      <activity role='clinician' action='Order and perform ECG to detect atrial fibrillation and other acute arrhythmias (should not delay acute treatment or imaging)' objects='patient, ECG' id='activity2-3'/>
    </branch>
  </parallelGateway>
</process>
Advisor's suggestion:
Suggested modification: Move the activity "Provide cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies to all patients (admitted or discharged)" (id='activity18') to the end of the process, immediately before the process end tag, so that it occurs after all other diagnostic and management activities are completed.

Reason: According to extra knowledge point 1, the cross-continuum secondary prevention activity should be the last activity before process completion, ensuring that all acute assessment and management steps are finished prior to secondary prevention planning. This sequencing better reflects clinical workflow and guideline intent.
You need to modify the process text according to the suggestions and output it.
Be careful not to change the format:

When the process starts, please output '<process>'
An activity is represented as follows:
<activity role='' action='' objects='' id=''/>
The exclusive gateway is represented as follows:
<exclusiveGateway id=''>
  <branch condition='' id=''>
    <activity role='' action='' objects='' id=''/>
  </branch>
  <branch condition='' id=''>
    <activity role='' action='' objects='' id=''/>
  </branch>
</exclusiveGateway>
The parallel gateway is represented as follows:
<parallelGateway id=''>
  <branch id=''>
    <activity role='' action='' objects='' id=''/>
  </branch>
  <branch id=''>
    <activity role='' action='' objects='' id=''/>
  </branch>
</parallelGateway>
The inclusive gateway is represented as follows:
<inclusiveGateway id=''>
  <branch condition='' id=''>
    <activity role='' action='' objects='' id=''/>
  </branch>
  <branch condition='' id=''>
    <activity role='' action='' objects='' id=''/>
  </branch>
</inclusiveGateway>
At the end of the process, please output '</process>'

There are a few requirements that should be noted when generating process text:
    1) role, action, objects and id in an activity represent the subject of the activity, the activity behavior, the items needed to perform in the activity and the activity id, respectively.
    2) There are at least two branches within the exclusive gateway and the parallel gateway.
    3) Activity, gateway, and branch id attributes must be unique.
    4) When the branch in the exclusive gateway has a condition, fill the condition into the condition attribute. When the branch unconditional within the exclusive gateway, the condition attribute of the branch =''. However, all branches within a exclusive gateway can only be conditional, or both unconditional.
    5) The branch in the parallel gateway has no condition attribute.
    6) Each branch in the inclusive gateway must have condition.
    7) There must be at least one activity inside the branch tag.
    8) The activity of a sequential relation need not be represented by a gateway, that is, there is no 'sequenceGateway' label.


[2025-30-06 14:03:02 INFO] flask app.py did not start for online log
[2025-30-06 14:03:09 INFO] HTTP Request: POST https://api.openai.com/v1/chat/completions "HTTP/1.1 200 OK"
[2025-30-06 14:03:09 INFO] **[OpenAI_Usage_Info Receive]**
prompt_tokens: 5784
completion_tokens: 1599
total_tokens: 7383


[2025-30-06 14:03:09 INFO] flask app.py did not start for online log
[2025-30-06 14:03:09 INFO] Process design expert: **Process design expert<->Knowledge Graph Advisor on : ProcessDesignerFix, turn 0**

[You're a Knowledge Graph Advisor. Now, we share a common interest in collaborating to successfully complete a task assigned by a new customer.
You are familiar with exclusive gateway, parallel gateway and inclusive gateway in BPMN. Your job is to review process models and provide actionable suggestions for improvement, one at a time.
You use extra knowledge provided to you to inform your suggestions. Your main responsibilities include giving suggestions and your reasoning to the process design expert.
Here is a new customer's task: Module 1: Early Assessment
This module identifies best practices for the early assessment of suspected stroke. Patients typically
present at the ED, but the same practices should be followed at an outpatient clinic or when patients
are directly admitted to acute care. The recommendations emphasize assessing the patient to inform
clinical decision-making and determine the most appropriate pathway.
Module 1 Recommended Practices 
1.1 Initial evaluation
1.1.1 Rapid initial evaluation should be conducted for airway,
breathing, and circulation
1.2 Initial examinations
1.2.1 All patients should undergo a neurological examination to
determine focal neurological deficits and assess stroke severity on a
standardized stroke scale (NIHSS or CNS for stroke)
1.2.2 Patients presenting with potentially disabling, acute neurological
symptoms suggestive of an acute stroke within 6.0 hours of symptom
onset, and may be considered for those in whom treatment can be
initiated within a 12- hour window from stroke symptom onset, who
meet clinical and imaging criteria may be considered for endovascular
therapy
1.2.3 All patients with suspected acute stroke (presenting within acute
stroke treatment time window) should undergo rapid brain imaging
(non-contrast CT or MRI) and CTA (Door to CT/CTA should be less
than twenty five minutes)
1.2.4. For patients with acute ischemic stroke that are clinically eligible
for acute stroke treatments, advanced CT imaging including CT and
multiphase CTA or Perfusion CT should be considered.
1.2.5 Brain imaging should be interpreted immediately by a health care
provider with expertise in reading/interpreting CT/CTA and/or MRI of
the brain
1.2.6 All patients should undergo ECG to detect atrial fibrillation and
other acute arrhythmias but should not delay acute treatment
1.2.7 A chest x-ray should not delay assessment for thrombolysis 
1.2.8 All patients should have the following blood work:
• CBC
• electrolytes
• creatinine
• glucose
• INR
• partial thromboplastin time
• troponin test (if clinically indicated)
1.3 Assessment and early management of dysphagia
1.3.1 All patients with stroke should be made NPO initially and have
their swallowing ability screened using a simple, valid, reliable, bedside
testing protocol as part of their initial assessment and before initiating
oral medication, fluid, or food
1.3.2 All patients with stroke who are not alert within the first 24 hours
should be monitored closely, and swallowing ability should be
screened when clinically appropriate
1.3.3 Patients with stroke presenting with features indicating dysphagia
or pulmonary aspiration should receive a full clinical assessment of
their swallowing ability by a speech-language pathologist or
appropriately trained specialist who would advise on swallowing ability
and the required consistency of diet and fluids
1.4 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies
1.4.1 All patients, whether admitted to hospital or discharged from the
ED, should be given appropriate cross-continuum secondary
prevention assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10)
1.5 Recommendation is not applicable to ischemic or ICH stroke patients
1.6 Initial examinations for ischemic stroke
1.6.1 Recommendation is not applicable to ischemic stroke patients
1.6.2 All other patients (presenting beyond 48 hours) with a TIA or
ischemic stroke should undergo vascular imaging of the brain and
neck arteries as soon as possible
1.7 Initial examinations for ICH
1.7.1 Patients with ICH must be treated as a medical emergency. ICH
should be promptly recognized, and patients should be evaluated
immediately by physicians with expertise in stroke management
1.7.2 Evaluation of patients with acute ICH should include questions
about anticoagulant therapy, measurement of platelet count, PTT, and
INR
1.7.3 Select patients with ICH should have CTA or MRA as soon as
possible
Abbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; Australia, Australian Clinical Guidelines for Stroke
Management; CBC, complete blood count; CSBPR, Canadian Stroke Best Practices Recommendations; CNS, Canadian Neurological Scale;
CT, computerized tomography; CTA, computed tomography angiography; ECG, electrocardiogram; ED, emergency department;EVT,
Endovascular Treatment ICH, intracerebral hemorrhage; INR, international normalized ratio; MRA, magnetic resonance angiography; MRI,
magnetic resonance imaging; NHS/NICE, National Collaborating Centre for Chronic Conditions; NIHSS, National Institute of Health Stroke
Scale; NPO, nil per os (nothing by mouth); PTT, partial thromboplastin time; SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network; TIA, transient
ischemic attack.

The following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel.

Module 1 Implementation Considerations
General considerations
• Development and/or updating of ED acute stroke protocols to ensure communication with CritiCall Ontario as soon as
possible to determine treatment and transport decisions for patients presenting with potentially disabling, acute
neurological symptoms suggestive of an acute stroke within 6.0 hours of symptom onset and considered to be a
potential candidate for intravenous thrombolysis and/or endovascular therapy (EVT)
• Regional planning for access to acute stroke EVT should consider the following:
o The importance of rapid triage, assessment and brain imaging (including parallel vascular imaging) of acute
stroke patients who are potential candidates for EVT.
o Development of regional and provincial bypass and repatriation agreements
o Sites should establish rapid communication protocols with closest EVT site(s), facilitated through CritiCall
Ontario.
o Development of regional protocols to support a “drip and ship” process.
• Capacity Planning is needed to develop access to EVT for patients living within regions where currently there is a
greater than two (2) hour patient transfer time to an EVT Centre
• Where feasible, development of processes and protocols to facilitate EMS to divert patients to regional or district
stroke and /Endovascular Treatment centres if there is suspicion of stroke
• The process for EMS prenotification of the receiving stroke hospital about a stroke patient arrival should be better
established to ensure acute stroke teams receive timely and detailed information
• Collaboration between local EMS and institutions that provide stroke services should occur in all stroke networks
across the province to support quality improvement initiatives that facilitate access to stroke care
• Ongoing education should be provided to EMS crews about the recognition of stroke symptoms and regional medical
redirect protocols, including time sensitive treatments such as thrombolysis,EVT, patient transport monitoring and
management.
• Upon receiving EMS prenotification, the receiving hospital’s acute stroke team should be contacted and called to the
ED (for appropriate patients)
• Standardized stroke assessment and treatment protocols/tools should be developed and used in all Ontario hospital
EDs
• Access should be increased in all hospitals to either stroke physician experts or radiologists who can interpret brain
imaging urgently and allow for full assessment and treatment with tPA thrombolysis within target door to needle time
of less than 60 minutes in 90% of treated patients and a median door to needle time of 30 mins. of patient arrival for
appropriate patients
• Sufficient human resources capacity should be ensured so that patients can be diagnosed and treated in a timely
manner
• To facilitate early assessment, hospital-level CTAS I or CTAS II access to diagnostic imaging should be established
for suspected stroke patients
• Rapid turnaround times for lab work should be negotiated in hospitals that provide tPA thrombolysis for ischemic
stroke patients to facilitate rapid assessment and treatment
• Efforts to raise public awareness about the symptoms of stroke and when to contact 911 should continue to be
enhanced and funded
• Capacity planning to ensure access to CT/CTA should include:
o Training for CT technologists
o Adoption of provincial CT/CTA Protocol
o Human resource availability
o Communication processes with EVT Centre experts
Abbreviations: CTAS, Canadian Triage and Acuity Scale; ED, emergency department; EMS, emergency medical services; tPA, tissue
plasminogen activator..]

<process>
  <activity role='triage nurse' action='Conduct rapid initial evaluation for airway, breathing, and circulation' objects='patient' id='activity1-abc'/>
  <activity role='clinician' action='Perform neurological examination including assessment of stroke severity using standardized stroke scale (NIHSS or CNS)' objects='patient' id='activity2-1-2'/>
  <parallelGateway id='parallelgateway1'>
    <branch id='branch1'>
      <activity role='clinician' action='Determine if patient presents with potentially disabling, acute neurological symptoms suggestive of acute stroke within 6 hours of symptom onset and if treatment can be initiated within 12 hours' objects='patient history, symptom onset time' id='activity3'/>
      <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway1'>
        <branch condition='Meets criteria for endovascular therapy consideration' id='branch2'>
          <activity role='clinician' action='Consider patient for endovascular therapy (EVT) if clinical and imaging criteria are met' objects='clinical criteria, imaging criteria' id='activity4'/>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='Does not meet criteria for endovascular therapy consideration' id='branch3'>
          <activity role='clinician' action='Proceed with standard acute stroke assessment and management' objects='patient' id='activity5'/>
        </branch>
      </exclusiveGateway>
    </branch>
    <branch id='branch4'>
      <activity role='radiology technologist' action='Perform rapid brain imaging (non-contrast CT or MRI) and CTA within 25 minutes of arrival' objects='patient, CT/MRI scanner, CTA' id='activity6'/>
      <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway2'>
        <branch condition='Patient is clinically eligible for acute ischemic stroke treatments' id='branch5'>
          <activity role='radiology technologist' action='Perform advanced CT imaging including CT, multiphase CTA or Perfusion CT' objects='patient, advanced CT imaging' id='activity7'/>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='Patient is not clinically eligible for acute ischemic stroke treatments' id='branch6'>
          <activity role='radiology technologist' action='Skip advanced CT imaging' objects='' id='activity8'/>
        </branch>
      </exclusiveGateway>
      <activity role='stroke physician or radiologist' action='Interpret brain imaging immediately' objects='CT/CTA/MRI images' id='activity9'/>
    </branch>
    <branch id='branch8'>
      <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway-chestxray'>
        <branch condition='Chest x-ray clinically indicated' id='branch8-1'>
          <activity role='clinician' action='Order chest x-ray (should not delay assessment for thrombolysis)' objects='patient, chest x-ray' id='activity11'/>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='Chest x-ray not clinically indicated' id='branch8-2'>
          <activity role='clinician' action='Do not order chest x-ray' objects='patient' id='activity11-2'/>
        </branch>
      </exclusiveGateway>
    </branch>
    <branch id='branch9'>
      <activity role='clinician' action='Order blood work' objects='patient' id='activity12-1'/>
      <activity role='nurse or phlebotomist' action='Collect blood samples' objects='patient, blood collection materials' id='activity12-2'/>
      <activity role='nurse or phlebotomist' action='Send blood samples to laboratory' objects='blood samples, laboratory' id='activity12-3'/>
    </branch>
    <branch id='branch10'>
      <activity role='nurse' action='Make all patients with stroke NPO initially and screen swallowing ability using simple, valid, reliable bedside protocol before oral medication, fluid, or food' objects='patient, swallowing screening tool' id='activity13'/>
      <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway3'>
        <branch condition='Patient not alert within first 24 hours' id='branch11'>
          <activity role='nurse' action='Monitor closely and screen swallowing ability when clinically appropriate' objects='patient' id='activity14'/>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='Patient alert within first 24 hours' id='branch12'>
          <activity role='nurse' action='Continue standard monitoring' objects='patient' id='activity15'/>
        </branch>
      </exclusiveGateway>
      <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway4'>
        <branch condition='Patient presents with features indicating dysphagia or pulmonary aspiration' id='branch13'>
          <activity role='speech-language pathologist or trained specialist' action='Perform full clinical assessment of swallowing ability and advise on swallowing and required consistency of diet and fluids' objects='patient' id='activity16'/>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='No features of dysphagia or pulmonary aspiration' id='branch14'>
          <activity role='nurse' action='Continue routine care' objects='patient' id='activity17'/>
        </branch>
      </exclusiveGateway>
    </branch>
    <branch id='branch12'>
      <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway5'>
        <branch condition='Patient presenting beyond 48 hours with TIA or ischemic stroke' id='branch15'>
          <activity role='clinician' action='Order vascular imaging of brain and neck arteries as soon as possible' objects='patient, vascular imaging' id='activity19'/>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='Patient presenting within 48 hours or not TIA/ischemic stroke' id='branch16'>
          <activity role='clinician' action='Proceed with standard care' objects='patient' id='activity20'/>
        </branch>
      </exclusiveGateway>
    </branch>
    <branch id='branch13'>
      <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway6'>
        <branch condition='Patient has ICH' id='branch17'>
          <activity role='stroke physician' action='Recognize ICH as medical emergency and evaluate immediately' objects='patient' id='activity21'/>
          <activity role='stroke physician' action='Assess anticoagulant therapy, measure platelet count, PTT, and INR' objects='patient, lab results' id='activity22'/>
          <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway7'>
            <branch condition='Select ICH patients as indicated' id='branch18'>
              <activity role='radiology technologist' action='Perform CTA or MRA as soon as possible' objects='patient, CTA/MRA' id='activity23'/>
            </branch>
            <branch condition='Not indicated for CTA/MRA' id='branch19'>
              <activity role='stroke physician' action='Continue with standard ICH management' objects='patient' id='activity24'/>
            </branch>
          </exclusiveGateway>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='Patient does not have ICH' id='branch20'>
          <activity role='clinician' action='Continue with appropriate stroke pathway' objects='patient' id='activity25'/>
        </branch>
      </exclusiveGateway>
    </branch>
    <branch id='branch14'>
      <activity role='clinician' action='Order and perform ECG to detect atrial fibrillation and other acute arrhythmias (should not delay acute treatment or imaging)' objects='patient, ECG' id='activity2-3'/>
    </branch>
  </parallelGateway>
  <activity role='clinician' action='Provide cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies to all patients (admitted or discharged)' objects='patient, prevention protocols' id='activity18'/>
</process>

| **task_prompt** | Module 1: Early Assessment This module identifies best practices for the early assessment of suspected stroke. Patients typically present at the ED, but the same practices should be followed at an outpatient clinic or when patients are directly admitted to acute care. The recommendations emphasize assessing the patient to inform clinical decision-making and determine the most appropriate pathway. Module 1 Recommended Practices  1.1 Initial evaluation 1.1.1 Rapid initial evaluation should be conducted for airway, breathing, and circulation 1.2 Initial examinations 1.2.1 All patients should undergo a neurological examination to determine focal neurological deficits and assess stroke severity on a standardized stroke scale (NIHSS or CNS for stroke) 1.2.2 Patients presenting with potentially disabling, acute neurological symptoms suggestive of an acute stroke within 6.0 hours of symptom onset, and may be considered for those in whom treatment can be initiated within a 12- hour window from stroke symptom onset, who meet clinical and imaging criteria may be considered for endovascular therapy 1.2.3 All patients with suspected acute stroke (presenting within acute stroke treatment time window) should undergo rapid brain imaging (non-contrast CT or MRI) and CTA (Door to CT/CTA should be less than twenty five minutes) 1.2.4. For patients with acute ischemic stroke that are clinically eligible for acute stroke treatments, advanced CT imaging including CT and multiphase CTA or Perfusion CT should be considered. 1.2.5 Brain imaging should be interpreted immediately by a health care provider with expertise in reading/interpreting CT/CTA and/or MRI of the brain 1.2.6 All patients should undergo ECG to detect atrial fibrillation and other acute arrhythmias but should not delay acute treatment 1.2.7 A chest x-ray should not delay assessment for thrombolysis  1.2.8 All patients should have the following blood work: • CBC • electrolytes • creatinine • glucose • INR • partial thromboplastin time • troponin test (if clinically indicated) 1.3 Assessment and early management of dysphagia 1.3.1 All patients with stroke should be made NPO initially and have their swallowing ability screened using a simple, valid, reliable, bedside testing protocol as part of their initial assessment and before initiating oral medication, fluid, or food 1.3.2 All patients with stroke who are not alert within the first 24 hours should be monitored closely, and swallowing ability should be screened when clinically appropriate 1.3.3 Patients with stroke presenting with features indicating dysphagia or pulmonary aspiration should receive a full clinical assessment of their swallowing ability by a speech-language pathologist or appropriately trained specialist who would advise on swallowing ability and the required consistency of diet and fluids 1.4 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies 1.4.1 All patients, whether admitted to hospital or discharged from the ED, should be given appropriate cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10) 1.5 Recommendation is not applicable to ischemic or ICH stroke patients 1.6 Initial examinations for ischemic stroke 1.6.1 Recommendation is not applicable to ischemic stroke patients 1.6.2 All other patients (presenting beyond 48 hours) with a TIA or ischemic stroke should undergo vascular imaging of the brain and neck arteries as soon as possible 1.7 Initial examinations for ICH 1.7.1 Patients with ICH must be treated as a medical emergency. ICH should be promptly recognized, and patients should be evaluated immediately by physicians with expertise in stroke management 1.7.2 Evaluation of patients with acute ICH should include questions about anticoagulant therapy, measurement of platelet count, PTT, and INR 1.7.3 Select patients with ICH should have CTA or MRA as soon as possible Abbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; Australia, Australian Clinical Guidelines for Stroke Management; CBC, complete blood count; CSBPR, Canadian Stroke Best Practices Recommendations; CNS, Canadian Neurological Scale; CT, computerized tomography; CTA, computed tomography angiography; ECG, electrocardiogram; ED, emergency department;EVT, Endovascular Treatment ICH, intracerebral hemorrhage; INR, international normalized ratio; MRA, magnetic resonance angiography; MRI, magnetic resonance imaging; NHS/NICE, National Collaborating Centre for Chronic Conditions; NIHSS, National Institute of Health Stroke Scale; NPO, nil per os (nothing by mouth); PTT, partial thromboplastin time; SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network; TIA, transient ischemic attack. The following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel. Module 1 Implementation Considerations General considerations • Development and/or updating of ED acute stroke protocols to ensure communication with CritiCall Ontario as soon as possible to determine treatment and transport decisions for patients presenting with potentially disabling, acute neurological symptoms suggestive of an acute stroke within 6.0 hours of symptom onset and considered to be a potential candidate for intravenous thrombolysis and/or endovascular therapy (EVT) • Regional planning for access to acute stroke EVT should consider the following: o The importance of rapid triage, assessment and brain imaging (including parallel vascular imaging) of acute stroke patients who are potential candidates for EVT. o Development of regional and provincial bypass and repatriation agreements o Sites should establish rapid communication protocols with closest EVT site(s), facilitated through CritiCall Ontario. o Development of regional protocols to support a “drip and ship” process. • Capacity Planning is needed to develop access to EVT for patients living within regions where currently there is a greater than two (2) hour patient transfer time to an EVT Centre • Where feasible, development of processes and protocols to facilitate EMS to divert patients to regional or district stroke and /Endovascular Treatment centres if there is suspicion of stroke • The process for EMS prenotification of the receiving stroke hospital about a stroke patient arrival should be better established to ensure acute stroke teams receive timely and detailed information • Collaboration between local EMS and institutions that provide stroke services should occur in all stroke networks across the province to support quality improvement initiatives that facilitate access to stroke care • Ongoing education should be provided to EMS crews about the recognition of stroke symptoms and regional medical redirect protocols, including time sensitive treatments such as thrombolysis,EVT, patient transport monitoring and management. • Upon receiving EMS prenotification, the receiving hospital’s acute stroke team should be contacted and called to the ED (for appropriate patients) • Standardized stroke assessment and treatment protocols/tools should be developed and used in all Ontario hospital EDs • Access should be increased in all hospitals to either stroke physician experts or radiologists who can interpret brain imaging urgently and allow for full assessment and treatment with tPA thrombolysis within target door to needle time of less than 60 minutes in 90% of treated patients and a median door to needle time of 30 mins. of patient arrival for appropriate patients • Sufficient human resources capacity should be ensured so that patients can be diagnosed and treated in a timely manner • To facilitate early assessment, hospital-level CTAS I or CTAS II access to diagnostic imaging should be established for suspected stroke patients • Rapid turnaround times for lab work should be negotiated in hospitals that provide tPA thrombolysis for ischemic stroke patients to facilitate rapid assessment and treatment • Efforts to raise public awareness about the symptoms of stroke and when to contact 911 should continue to be enhanced and funded • Capacity planning to ensure access to CT/CTA should include: o Training for CT technologists o Adoption of provincial CT/CTA Protocol o Human resource availability o Communication processes with EVT Centre experts Abbreviations: CTAS, Canadian Triage and Acuity Scale; ED, emergency department; EMS, emergency medical services; tPA, tissue plasminogen activator. |
| **need_reflect** | False |
| **assistant_role_name** | Knowledge Graph Advisor |
| **user_role_name** | Team leader |
| **phase_prompt** | Current process text: {reviewed_process_text} Extra knowledge: 1) The activity 'Provide cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies...' should be the last activity after everything else is done and before the end activity. 2) Activities related to stroke units, staffing, or hospitals in the QBP should be prioritized as the initial steps in their respective flow or branch. 3) All tests, including any type of imaging and blood tests, should be immediately interpreted by a healthcare expert. 4) Blood tests or any tests that take a long time toget results should occur concurrently with other activities unless required for a specific task, in which case they will be merged into the flow or branch of that activity. 5) Activities related to stroke units, staffing, or hospitals in the QBP should be put in a single activity. 6) Assessing airway, breathing, and circulation is called ABC testing and is ONE activity. 7) Neurological examination and imaging results are needed to Evaluate patients for endovascular therapy. However, they can be in parallel to other activities that don’ t need these results. 8) CBC, electrolytes, creatinine, glucose, INR, partial thromboplastin time, and troponin test are all types of blood tests, and they can all be in ONE blood works activity if they are at the same place of a process. 9) Anti platelet therapy has 4 general options(ASA, Clopidogrel, Extended - release Dipyridamole + Aspirin(Aggrenox), and rectal or gastric ASA if can 't swallow) and they should be indicated right after each initiation of antiplatelet therapy activity in the process.  10) Temperature reducing activities should happen in parallel. 11) The activity 'chest x-ray should not delay...' should have a skip flow as it should be skipped if not needed. 12) If activity 'should be evaluated in the ED to be considered for admission to hospital' is needed, it should happen in parallel and not in sequence. 13) When patients should be screened / assessed for diabetes, dental issues, cognitive impairment, and depression in the same part of the process, they should be merged into one activity along with forwarding the results. 14) Assessments related and needed to formulating management plan should be merged into one activity along with formulating the management plan. 15) Formulating the management plan should happen before the activities and assessments after it. 16) Between 24 - 48 hour of stroke onset IF no contradiction, mobilization is encouraged. However, in the first 24 hour it is only encouraged IF clinical judgement suggests otherwise, it is not.  When making recommendations, don't forget the format of the process text: {format} Format your suggestion in the following format: Suggested modification:  Reason:  Based on the above extra knowledge, provide ONE actionable suggestion along with your reasoning to improve the process. If there are no further suggestions, just reply with: 'There are no further suggestions.' |
| **phase_name** | KnowledgeGraphSuggestion |
| **assistant_role_prompt** | You're a Knowledge Graph Advisor. Now, we share a common interest in collaborating to successfully complete a task assigned by a new customer. You are familiar with exclusive gateway, parallel gateway and inclusive gateway in BPMN. Your job is to review process models and provide actionable suggestions for improvement, one at a time. You use extra knowledge provided to you to inform your suggestions. Your main responsibilities include giving suggestions and your reasoning to the process design expert. Here is a new customer's task: {task}. |

Your main responsibilities will include guiding the process design expert through process generation, process refinement, and so on. Here is a new customer's task: {task}. To complete the task, I will give you one or more instructions, and you must help me to write a specific solution that appropriately solves the requested instruction based on your expertise and my needs. |

| **placeholders** | {'cycle_num': 5, 'cycle_index': 1, 'task': 'Module 1: Early Assessment\nThis module identifies best practices for the early assessment of suspected stroke. Patients typically\npresent at the ED, but the same practices should be followed at an outpatient clinic or when patients\nare directly admitted to acute care. The recommendations emphasize assessing the patient to inform\nclinical decision-making and determine the most appropriate pathway.\nModule 1 Recommended Practices \n1.1 Initial evaluation\n1.1.1 Rapid initial evaluation should be conducted for airway,\nbreathing, and circulation\n1.2 Initial examinations\n1.2.1 All patients should undergo a neurological examination to\ndetermine focal neurological deficits and assess stroke severity on a\nstandardized stroke scale (NIHSS or CNS for stroke)\n1.2.2 Patients presenting with potentially disabling, acute neurological\nsymptoms suggestive of an acute stroke within 6.0 hours of symptom\nonset, and may be considered for those in whom treatment can be\ninitiated within a 12- hour window from stroke symptom onset, who\nmeet clinical and imaging criteria may be considered for endovascular\ntherapy\n1.2.3 All patients with suspected acute stroke (presenting within acute\nstroke treatment time window) should undergo rapid brain imaging\n(non-contrast CT or MRI) and CTA (Door to CT/CTA should be less\nthan twenty five minutes)\n1.2.4. For patients with acute ischemic stroke that are clinically eligible\nfor acute stroke treatments, advanced CT imaging including CT and\nmultiphase CTA or Perfusion CT should be considered.\n1.2.5 Brain imaging should be interpreted immediately by a health care\nprovider with expertise in reading/interpreting CT/CTA and/or MRI of\nthe brain\n1.2.6 All patients should undergo ECG to detect atrial fibrillation and\nother acute arrhythmias but should not delay acute treatment\n1.2.7 A chest x-ray should not delay assessment for thrombolysis \n1.2.8 All patients should have the following blood work:\n• CBC\n• electrolytes\n• creatinine\n• glucose\n• INR\n• partial thromboplastin time\n• troponin test (if clinically indicated)\n1.3 Assessment and early management of dysphagia\n1.3.1 All patients with stroke should be made NPO initially and have\ntheir swallowing ability screened using a simple, valid, reliable, bedside\ntesting protocol as part of their initial assessment and before initiating\noral medication, fluid, or food\n1.3.2 All patients with stroke who are not alert within the first 24 hours\nshould be monitored closely, and swallowing ability should be\nscreened when clinically appropriate\n1.3.3 Patients with stroke presenting with features indicating dysphagia\nor pulmonary aspiration should receive a full clinical assessment of\ntheir swallowing ability by a speech-language pathologist or\nappropriately trained specialist who would advise on swallowing ability\nand the required consistency of diet and fluids\n1.4 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies\n1.4.1 All patients, whether admitted to hospital or discharged from the\nED, should be given appropriate cross-continuum secondary\nprevention assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10)\n1.5 Recommendation is not applicable to ischemic or ICH stroke patients\n1.6 Initial examinations for ischemic stroke\n1.6.1 Recommendation is not applicable to ischemic stroke patients\n1.6.2 All other patients (presenting beyond 48 hours) with a TIA or\nischemic stroke should undergo vascular imaging of the brain and\nneck arteries as soon as possible\n1.7 Initial examinations for ICH\n1.7.1 Patients with ICH must be treated as a medical emergency. ICH\nshould be promptly recognized, and patients should be evaluated\nimmediately by physicians with expertise in stroke management\n1.7.2 Evaluation of patients with acute ICH should include questions\nabout anticoagulant therapy, measurement of platelet count, PTT, and\nINR\n1.7.3 Select patients with ICH should have CTA or MRA as soon as\npossible\nAbbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; Australia, Australian Clinical Guidelines for Stroke\nManagement; CBC, complete blood count; CSBPR, Canadian Stroke Best Practices Recommendations; CNS, Canadian Neurological Scale;\nCT, computerized tomography; CTA, computed tomography angiography; ECG, electrocardiogram; ED, emergency department;EVT,\nEndovascular Treatment ICH, intracerebral hemorrhage; INR, international normalized ratio; MRA, magnetic resonance angiography; MRI,\nmagnetic resonance imaging; NHS/NICE, National Collaborating Centre for Chronic Conditions; NIHSS, National Institute of Health Stroke\nScale; NPO, nil per os (nothing by mouth); PTT, partial thromboplastin time; SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network; TIA, transient\nischemic attack.\n\nThe following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel.\n\nModule 1 Implementation Considerations\nGeneral considerations\n• Development and/or updating of ED acute stroke protocols to ensure communication with CritiCall Ontario as soon as\npossible to determine treatment and transport decisions for patients presenting with potentially disabling, acute\nneurological symptoms suggestive of an acute stroke within 6.0 hours of symptom onset and considered to be a\npotential candidate for intravenous thrombolysis and/or endovascular therapy (EVT)\n• Regional planning for access to acute stroke EVT should consider the following:\no The importance of rapid triage, assessment and brain imaging (including parallel vascular imaging) of acute\nstroke patients who are potential candidates for EVT.\no Development of regional and provincial bypass and repatriation agreements\no Sites should establish rapid communication protocols with closest EVT site(s), facilitated through CritiCall\nOntario.\no Development of regional protocols to support a “drip and ship” process.\n• Capacity Planning is needed to develop access to EVT for patients living within regions where currently there is a\ngreater than two (2) hour patient transfer time to an EVT Centre\n• Where feasible, development of processes and protocols to facilitate EMS to divert patients to regional or district\nstroke and /Endovascular Treatment centres if there is suspicion of stroke\n• The process for EMS prenotification of the receiving stroke hospital about a stroke patient arrival should be better\nestablished to ensure acute stroke teams receive timely and detailed information\n• Collaboration between local EMS and institutions that provide stroke services should occur in all stroke networks\nacross the province to support quality improvement initiatives that facilitate access to stroke care\n• Ongoing education should be provided to EMS crews about the recognition of stroke symptoms and regional medical\nredirect protocols, including time sensitive treatments such as thrombolysis,EVT, patient transport monitoring and\nmanagement.\n• Upon receiving EMS prenotification, the receiving hospital’s acute stroke team should be contacted and called to the\nED (for appropriate patients)\n• Standardized stroke assessment and treatment protocols/tools should be developed and used in all Ontario hospital\nEDs\n• Access should be increased in all hospitals to either stroke physician experts or radiologists who can interpret brain\nimaging urgently and allow for full assessment and treatment with tPA thrombolysis within target door to needle time\nof less than 60 minutes in 90% of treated patients and a median door to needle time of 30 mins. of patient arrival for\nappropriate patients\n• Sufficient human resources capacity should be ensured so that patients can be diagnosed and treated in a timely\nmanner\n• To facilitate early assessment, hospital-level CTAS I or CTAS II access to diagnostic imaging should be established\nfor suspected stroke patients\n• Rapid turnaround times for lab work should be negotiated in hospitals that provide tPA thrombolysis for ischemic\nstroke patients to facilitate rapid assessment and treatment\n• Efforts to raise public awareness about the symptoms of stroke and when to contact 911 should continue to be\nenhanced and funded\n• Capacity planning to ensure access to CT/CTA should include:\no Training for CT technologists\no Adoption of provincial CT/CTA Protocol\no Human resource availability\no Communication processes with EVT Centre experts\nAbbreviations: CTAS, Canadian Triage and Acuity Scale; ED, emergency department; EMS, emergency medical services; tPA, tissue\nplasminogen activator.', 'reviewed_process_text': "\n  \n  \n  \n    \n      \n      \n        \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n      \n    \n    \n      \n      \n        \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n      \n      \n    \n    \n      \n        \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n      \n    \n    \n      \n      \n      \n    \n    \n      \n      \n        \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n      \n      \n        \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n      \n    \n    \n      \n        \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n      \n    \n    \n      \n        \n          \n          \n          \n            \n              \n            \n            \n              \n            \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n      \n    \n    \n      \n    \n  \n  \n", 'extra_knowledge': '', 'format': "\nWhen the process starts, please output ''\nAn activity is represented as follows:\n\nThe exclusive gateway is represented as follows:\n\n  \n    \n  \n  \n    \n  \n\nThe parallel gateway is represented as follows:\n\n  \n    \n  \n  \n    \n  \n\nThe inclusive gateway is represented as follows:\n\n  \n    \n  \n  \n    \n  \n\nAt the end of the process, please output ''\n\nThere are a few requirements that should be noted when generating process text:\n    1) role, action, objects and id in an activity represent the subject of the activity, the activity behavior, the items needed to perform in the activity and the activity id, respectively.\n    2) There are at least two branches within the exclusive gateway and the parallel gateway.\n    3) Activity, gateway, and branch id attributes must be unique.\n    4) When the branch in the exclusive gateway has a condition, fill the condition into the condition attribute. When the branch unconditional within the exclusive gateway, the condition attribute of the branch =''. However, all branches within a exclusive gateway can only be conditional, or both unconditional.\n    5) The branch in the parallel gateway has no condition attribute.\n    6) Each branch in the inclusive gateway must have condition.\n    7) There must be at least one activity inside the branch tag.\n    8) The activity of a sequential relation need not be represented by a gateway, that is, there is no 'sequenceGateway' label.\n", 'examples': ' ', 'suggestions': 'Suggested modification: Move the activity "Provide cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies to all patients (admitted or discharged)" (id=\'activity18\') to the end of the process, immediately before the process end tag, so that it occurs after all other diagnostic and management activities are completed.\n\nReason: According to extra knowledge point 1, the cross-continuum secondary prevention activity should be the last activity before process completion, ensuring that all acute assessment and management steps are finished prior to secondary prevention planning. This sequencing better reflects clinical workflow and guideline intent.'} |

| **assistant_role_name** | Knowledge Graph Advisor |
| **user_role_name** | Team leader |
| **assistant_role_prompt** | You're a Knowledge Graph Advisor. Now, we share a common interest in collaborating to successfully complete a task assigned by a new customer. You are familiar with exclusive gateway, parallel gateway and inclusive gateway in BPMN. Your job is to review process models and provide actionable suggestions for improvement, one at a time. You use extra knowledge provided to you to inform your suggestions. Your main responsibilities include giving suggestions and your reasoning to the process design expert.
